It can be a lot of fun getting everything ready for a brand-new baby, but there’s also a lot of planning that goes into the delivery and day-to-day life with your new baby. To make things a little easier, I’ve put together some handy advice, links and a checklist of all the items you’ll need to pack for a hospital birth and bring with you when you go on outings together.
Packing for a hospital birth
It’s a good idea to pack your hospital go-bag when you’re about 8 months pregnant. Keep it next to your front door just in case you need to grab it in a hurry! There’s quite a lot you’ll want to put in there and it will probably be heavy, so it’s a good idea to opt for a medium to large trolley case.
While you wait
Pack some ways to keep your mind off your contractions. I recommend a couple of magazines, a tablet with your favourite movies pre-loaded and a pair of quality headphones to block out the noise around you while you watch.
Pack your own
While hospitals usually have the basic necessities, you might want to phone ahead and ask whether you should bring your own breast pump, baby bottles, formula, nappies and baby wipes or whether they will provide these. You will definitely want to bring your own comfy pillow, blanket, bath towel, bathrobe and snacks!
First photos with baby
Even if you don’t like photos, you will want at least one selfie with your new baby while you’re in hospital. It’s great to have a smartphone handy for this purpose, but don’t get caught with a dead battery! The Power On The Go bundle is the perfect thing to avoid this disaster. If you want to get the best photos possible, you might even want to invest in a professional camera.
Welcome, baby!
This is such a special moment, and you will want to celebrate it with a keepsake gift for baby that will last for decades to come. I suggest a super-soft Hug Me mink blanket. You should probably bring a few onesies, a beanie, socks and a few receiving blankets to keep him/her warm in the hospital. Your baby might be bigger than the average newborn, so remember to pack clothes suitable for a newborn and a 0-3-month-old!
Going home
If you’re going to leave the hospital in a car, the law requires that you install a safety-approved car seat rated for newborns. Make sure that you also have a baby carrier or pram suitable for newborns to get from A to B.

Going home
If you’re going to leave the hospital in a car, the law requires that you install a safety-approved car seat rated for newborns. Make sure that you also have a baby carrier or pram suitable for newborns to get from A to B.
Packing for outings
When you’re leaving the house with your baby, the first thing to consider is how to carry all your baby’s essentials! There are loads of mommy/nappy bags out there, but they aren’t created equal. Look out for one that is durable, easy to carry and is big enough for everything. I recommend getting the Moonlight baby hamper set because it includes a fantastic mommy backpack full of compartments, a changing mat, baby carrier, 4 receiving blankets and a hooded towel – so it’s great value for money.
Keep it together
Keep everything for changing nappies together and everything for feeding together. Airtight containers and resealable bags are very useful for keeping certain items together, keeping them hygienic and for preventing food from leaking everywhere.
Accidents happen
Pack an extra outfit for yourself and for your baby. Consider the weather and bring extra items to keep baby warm and protected from the sun as well as a small first-aid kit (you never know what’s going to happen).
Feeding time
As your baby grows, his/her needs will change, especially when it comes to feeding. I recommend carrying a breast pump with you if you’re breastfeeding (the Snookums electric breast pump is a very discreet option) and carrying baby-safe, spill-proof cups and bowls for toddlers (I recommend the Munchkin feeding bundle set).
You’ve seen all you need to pack for baby, but there are still loads more items you’ll need for your little one’s bedroom and bath time. Take some time to look through the HC Baby range. You will be surprised at just how much you can afford to get today and pay for over a few months.
ZOLISWA GABA
HomeChoice Socialite
